newsitem.title: USA: US-Mexico grain shipments slow to April-USFGC aide.
newsitem.headline: US-Mexico grain shipments slow to April-USFGC aide.

text.p: U.S. grain shipments to Mexico probably will endure paperwork delays for another month or two, a U.S. Feed Grains Council official said Monday.
"We don't see major relief before April," said Ricardo Celma, director of the council's Mexico City office.
The Mexican government has said it does not have the work force to keep up with demand for import permits.

Humberto Bonnell, the council's representative in South America, said grain importers in Colombia were worried about a U.S. decision due March 1 whether to certify the nation as adequately fighting drug smuggling.

"They're very concerned if there would be economic sanctions" and export controls if Colombia is decertified, Bonnell said at a news conference. Colombia is the leading market for U.S. feed grains in the region.
In the long run, Mexico should be a growing market for U.S. corn because of free trade pacts, Celma said.

Dennis Kitch, director of the council's Tokyo office, said there could be a "very strong" market in Japan for value enhanced feed grains. Production costs were rising and making high-quality raw materials attractive.
